items.title: Hugo Grotius and the minimalist theory of natural law
items.content_html:
More than 20 years ago I started to read the main works of Hugo Grotius. I was writing a thesis about the poet Andrew Marvell, and I wanted to try to clarify Marvell‚Äôs references to Grotius, particularly those in ‚ÄúThe Character of Holland‚Äù, a satire written during the first Anglo-Dutch war. Marvell‚Äôs poem refers to two of the Dutchman‚Äôs works, Mare liberum and De iure belli ac pacis, and effectively accuses the United Provinces of acting as if they owned the sea, though their famous theorist had insisted that the sea was incapable of being owned.

As I read the longer of the two works, I was immediately drawn to a question that seemed to me much more fundamental and of wider applicability than the lawfulness of claiming rights over the sea: the basis, if one could be found, of natural law, assuming that such a thing could be said to exist.

Theories of natural law hold that humans are subject to some obligations and duties that exist independently of and prior to any ‚Äúpositive‚Äù laws, by which is meant laws enacted by human institutions, such as lawmaking bodies or absolute monarchs. For much of human history, natural law theories were based in religion: the law of nature was thought to derive its force and validity from the will (and command) of God. But what happens when we no longer believe in God? Can we still take natural law seriously?

Jeremy Bentham (1748‚Äì1832) insisted that positive law was the only kind of law that was binding or enforceable. His opinion has been very influential. In practice, we‚Äôre almost all believers in positive law now, most of the time. A lawyer arguing a case, or advising a client on what can or can‚Äôt legally be done, will want to be able to point to a statutory provision or a previously decided case to support the argument. There is certainly a wide range of positive law to govern almost any area of human activity that you can think of, and more is regularly being enacted. But what about earlier times, before legislatures were so powerful and so busy? Were there any obligations that were already binding on humans in ‚Äúa state of nature‚Äù?

I‚Äôve long thought that, if you believe the Nuremberg trials were anything more legitimate than ‚Äúvictors‚Äô justice‚Äù ‚Äî merely the imposition of its will by the prevailing party on the defeated one ‚Äî you must effectively base that judgment on some idea of natural law, even if you call it something else. Where did that natural law come from?

The thing I was most excited to discover in Grotius‚Äôs writings was a possible answer to that question. I couldn‚Äôt imagine writing about Grotius without devoting substantial attention to the theory of natural law. That gave rise to two problems, though. I was writing about the theme of justice in Marvell‚Äôs works and, in the particular chapter I was then working on, about ‚ÄúGrotian concepts of justice‚Äù in some of his poems, particularly ‚ÄúThe Character of Holland‚Äù. The issue relevant to that poem was the argument between Grotius and the English lawyer and historian John Selden about ownership of the sea.

Selden‚Äôs and Grotius‚Äôs differing views on this topic could be traced back to their ideas about natural law, by way of their contrasting theories as to how private ownership came to exist in the first place. Selden firmly believed that all law emanated from the will of a competent authority, and that the natural law consists of nothing other than God‚Äôs command, whereas Grotius believed, as we‚Äôll see, something distinguishable from that. So I had some basis for bringing in a discussion of the differing theories of natural law, particularly as my theme was ‚Äújustice‚Äù. In doing so, though, I‚Äôd be straying quite far from Marvell‚Äôs poem, which has nothing to say about the bases for the conflicting theories, and is instead concerned to accuse the Dutch of hypocrisy for acting inconsistently with the principles of their own theorist. By widening the discussion to include the theoretical differences between Grotius and Selden, I‚Äôd be losing my focus on the subject of Marvell‚Äôs poem.

Then there was the other problem: the conception I had of Grotius‚Äôs theory of natural law had been questioned by historians of political thought, who had contested the idea, previously popular among legal theorists in particular, that Grotius had been a more-or-less disinterested philosopher or theoretician of legal principles who effectively founded the field of international law. I I wanted to delve into Grotian thought, I‚Äôd have to demonstrate that I was aware of these developments in intellectual history, but to do so meant diverting my attention even further from Marvell‚Äôs poem.

In the end, I put the whole lot in: Selden‚Äôs and Grotius‚Äôs conflicting ideas of natural law and the law of nations, their different accounts of the origins of property rights, the criticisms of more recent historians of ideas of the more traditional legal historians‚Äô picture of Grotius. It was only after 11 pages of this stuff that I came to discuss Marvell‚Äôs poem. No wonder the examiners of my thesis described it as ‚Äúuneven‚Äù, and suggested that it could have been noticeably shorter. (Mercifully, they didn‚Äôt ask for any changes, though.)

Rereading the chapter recently after a gap of several years, I could see that I should have cut the natural law discussion completely. I could then equally have done without the review of (relatively) recent reassessments of Grotius‚Äôs thought, and reduced the comparison of the contrasting theories about the origin of ownership to a more manageable paragraph or two. Unfortunately, I was quite unable to see this at the time. Mistakenly, I thought I couldn‚Äôt remove part of the argument without leaving loose threads which would end up unravelling the whole.

I wanted to say something about the Grotian ‚Äúminimalist‚Äù theory of natural law. Unfortunately, I was able to see that this topic was (a bit) more than tangentially relevant to the argument of my thesis, and I let myself go. It‚Äôs clear now that I ought to have written about it separately somewhere else. But at the time I was deep in the middle of my thesis, I didn‚Äôt have any other outlets ‚Äî no blog, for example ‚Äî and I couldn‚Äôt really think about writing a short, self-contained piece.

In Grotius‚Äôs theory, the natural law consists only of those fundamental precepts which are evident to all human beings by virtue of our rational nature (‚ÄòPreliminary Discourse‚Äô, VIII, Rights, pp. 86‚Äì7). Those precepts are binding on all people, including those who have a wholly erroneous, or no, idea of God (‚ÄòPreliminary Discourse‚Äô, XI, Rights, pp. 89‚Äì90). In other words, the natural law consists of those rules about which any rational being must think ‚Äúit could not be otherwise‚Äù. This law is binding on all humans by virtue of its self-evident necessity, and this is equally true of humans to whom the word of God has never been revealed. Indeed, the law would still be binding even if (something that Grotius admits could not be asserted without the greatest wickedness) there were no God.

So, Grotius has arguably succeeded in putting forward a basis for law which is both antecedent to positive law and independent of divine command.

The precepts of natural law include the obligation that people should be bound by their agreements and the obligations that they have assumed towards others. It‚Äôs on this principle that the whole edifice of government and systems of law, starting with the law of nations (ius gentium), is founded. Grotius says that the law of nations is based on the (common) will of all, or at least of many, nations. Acknowledging that, the law of nature apart, there is hardly any law that is universally accepted, he notes that the law of nations is thought to differ from one part of the world to another. But broadly speaking, the law of nations is binding on nations because at one time everybody who is subject to it, or their predecessors, agreed to it and they‚Äôre obliged to stand by their agreements.

Richard Tuck describes the Grotian conception of natural law as ‚Äúminimalist‚Äù, a label that is disputed by Johann P Sommerville, who points out that what Grotius has to say on the subject of natural rights is substantially the same as what had already been said by scholastic thinkers such as Suarez and Aquinas. According to Sommerville:

Su√°rez, for example, talked of natural law as obvious first principles of nature and reason, and precepts drawn from them by ‚Äòevident necessity.‚Äô Like Su√°rez and others, Grotius held that the laws of nature were deducible from a few principles, but he did not argue that the conclusions which could be drawn from those principles were minimal in number ‚Ä¶
SommervilleJohann P. Sommerville, ‚ÄúSelden, Grotius, and the Seventeenth-Century Intellectual Revolution in Moral and Political Theory‚Äù, in Victoria Kahn and Lorna Hutson, eds., Rhetoric and Law in Early Modern Europe (Yale University Press, 2001), 318‚Äì43; 333.

Grotius of course acknowledged a debt to Suarez and others but claimed to be treating the topic more systematically than those who had gone before, and in particular distinguishing between things that belonged in different categories. By recategorizing some things (notably rights of ownership) that had previously been considered part of the natural law as instead belonging to the law of nations, he undoubtedly reduced the scope of the former. It‚Äôs also true that the incomplete enumeration he attempted of the precepts of natural law has every appearance of minimalism:

‚Ä¶ to which belongs the Abstaining from that which is another‚Äôs, and the Restitution of what we have of another‚Äôs, or of the profit we have made by it, the Obligation of fulfilling Promises, the Reparation of a Damage done through our own Default, and the Merit of Punishment among Men‚Äô (‚ÄòPreliminary Discourse‚Äô, VIII, Rights, p. 86).
Grotius, RightsHugo Grotius, The Rights of War and Peace, ed. Richard Tuck (Liberty Fund, 2005), referred to as ‚ÄúRights‚Äù throughout this post.

I think it‚Äôs fair to summarize the broad general argument of the historians of ideas and/or political thought as saying that Grotius wasn‚Äôt the conscious and intentional innovator that he was often taken to be, particularly by credulous lawyers who didn‚Äôt know their history as well as they thought. No doubt some of those enthusiastic followers overlooked the degree to which his work is based on existing traditions, both scholastic and jurisprudential. But there‚Äôs plenty of evidence in the writings themselves that he believed he was doing something new, and it‚Äôs objectively true that something new emerged from his works, whatever may have been his intentions: the world now had a theory of natural law that did not depend on the will, the command, or even the existence of God.
items.summary: Traditionally, natural law theories have been grounded in the will or command of God. In the work of Hugo Grotius, we find a an argument for basing natural law instead on human reason. But did Grotius know what he was doing ‚Äî and does it matter?

items.title: Some books I didn‚Äôt leave behind a second time
items.content_html:
I spent an afternoon 2¬Ω years ago in my sister‚Äôs attic near Toulouse, deciding which of the books I had left there 9 years earlier I wanted to take back to Ireland and which I was prepared to abandon forever. The second group was much the larger, and I told my sister that she was welcome to do whatever she liked with them. Towards the end of last year, she let me know that they were still there, so I decided to go back and take a second bite at the cherry. Partly because of Talk about books, my priorities had changed: there were several books that I had been happy to leave behind before but that I now thought would be worth keeping after all. This time, I‚Äôd spend more than an afternoon going through the pile. I went for a week‚Äôs visit.

I quickly confirmed my suspicion that I had missed a box last time. Several books turned up that I had failed to find in 2020: my paperback copy of Ulysses, the first two of Kate Atkinson‚Äôs Jackson Brodie series, Candia McWilliam‚Äôs three novels, Steven Pinker‚Äôs The Blank Slate, Dibdin‚Äôs Dead Lagoon (which I had since replaced while writing about his Aurelio Zen series). I packed all of these. As I was inevitably going to take Ulysses, I decided that A Portrait of the Artist should come too, though I had intentionally left it behind the previous time.

But if I had found the box that was missing the first time, it seemed that a different one was eluding me now. I couldn‚Äôt find the Richard Tuck edition of Grotius, The Rights of War and Peace though I‚Äôm quite sure I‚Äôd seen the 3 hefty volumes when I was last there. If I had found them, would I have wanted to keep them? On the one hand, they had been quite expensive; on the other, I could probably get along without them very well. As it turns out, I don‚Äôt need to make up my mind about that.

In 2020, I had brought back only one Wilkie Collins, namely Armadale. This time, I added Basil, The Law and the Lady and The Moonstone; but where were No Name and The Woman in White? I had decided beforehand that I was going to take most of the Penguin Classics and Oxford World Classics that I‚Äôd come across, particularly if they were from the 19th century. So I got a few by Dickens and Austen: Little Dorrit, Our Mutual Friend and (I think ‚Äî it certainly should have been there) Bleak House; Emma and Persuasion and (almost certainly) Pride and Prejudice.

There was no Hardy, though I had been expecting to find a copy of Tess of the d‚ÄôUrbervilles at least. Something else I had been expecting to see but didn‚Äôt was the Penguin Classics Tristram Shandy introduced by Christopher Ricks. I‚Äôve never got very far into it before, but I think I might be ready for it now. Oh, well.

I knew in advance that I wasn‚Äôt going to want any Lawrence. Nor did I pack any Conrad (where was Nostromo?) or (as far as I can remember) Woolf; and the only Kipling I took was Plain Tales from the Hills, though I hesitated over Kim. (The Penguin Modern Classics covers are hard to resist.)

Last time, I had been glad to recover William Empson‚Äôs Collected Poems but had deliberately restricted myself to two volumes of his criticism, Seven Types of Ambiguity and Milton‚Äôs God. (I already had Using Biography in Ireland.) This time around, I put aside all the others I could find, intending to go through them to see if there was anything I couldn‚Äôt bear to be without. In the end, I didn‚Äôt bother to go through them, but packed them all: Some Versions of Pastoral, The Structure of Complex Words, Argufying and the first volume of Essays on Renaissance Literature. The second volume of Essays on Renaissance Literature must be in the ‚Äúmissing‚Äù box.

There were a few other individual books that I had specifically decided against taking last time, and about which I had second thoughts: Ian McEwan‚Äôs Atonement and Zadie Smith‚Äôs White Teeth being the most obvious examples. I had taken everything else by McEwan that I could find, so so it seemed a bit odd not to take Atonement too.

The books are in 4 small boxes under a table in my sister‚Äôs s√©jour, awaiting collection (with a 5th full of CDs). They ought (among other things), to fuel Talk about books for some time to come.
items.summary: In 2020, I rescued from my sister‚Äôs attic some of the books I‚Äôd left behind there years before. Recently, I went back for a second, final bite of the cherry.

items.title: Bringing back the CD ‚Äî but not the ‚Äújewel‚Äù case
items.content_html:
I‚Äôve just got home having spent a week in France visiting my youngest sister and her family. The last time I was there was 2¬Ω years ago, when I spent an afternoon sorting through the books I‚Äôd left behind in 2011, to see which ones I wanted to keep. At that time, I told my sister that she was welcome to throw out the rest, or dispose of them however she saw fit. She didn‚Äôt in fact get rid of any of them in the meantime, but eventually moved them out of the attic to the terrace, where they were slightly more vulnerable to damp. So, this time, I spent rather more than an afternoon sorting through them again, and salvaging four small boxes worth: partly because of Talk about books, my priorities have changed, and there were many books which I had happily abandoned in 2020 that I now thought I‚Äôd like to keep after all. I‚Äôm going to write about them, probably next weekend. First, though, I want to write about something else I thought I might have left behind for good: my CD collection.

Along with the books and some other odds and ends, when I left France in 2011 to return to Ireland, there were two substantial boxes of CDs. I had long since ripped all except a handful of them to an iTunes library stored on an external hard drive so I didn‚Äôt have many qualms about leaving the CDs behind. As well as the iTunes library, I had a succession of iPods, Walkmans and phones. Back in Ireland, I continued to buy physical CDs and download albums more or less indiscriminately. Most of the time, I didn‚Äôt have a CD player, so I invariably ripped the CDs and listened to the music on a variety of devices. Around 2017, after I‚Äôd bought the 4-CD set, Brad Mehldau, 10 Years Solo Live, I decided to rationalize my practice and buy only downloads from then on.

That habit lasted until 2020, when I wanted to buy Chick Corea‚Äôs Vigilette album, Tempus Fugit, which wasn‚Äôt available as a download. Gradually I started to buy CDs again. I even bought a CD player and began to listen to the CDs directly, rather than to the copies on my external hard drive or iPod Touch.

I should stress that as far as I‚Äôm concerned this isn‚Äôt a question of sound quality. I‚Äôm a music lover, not an audiophile, and I‚Äôm not able to distinguish aurally between the iTunes AAC or MP3 copies and the CD originals. I prefer to listen to the CD because I like the physical reminder that I have a particular album in my collection. In the case of a box set, like the Mehldau solo live album, I like having to change the disc rather than let the almost 5 hours of music play though continuously, as they do on iTunes/Apple Music. And, of course, I like having the liner notes in printed format.

So naturally I thought that while I was bringing home several boxes of books, I might as well see if I could fit in most of the CDs too. It was clear that this would be a less daunting prospect if I didn‚Äôt have to transport the ‚Äújewel‚Äù cases as well. About half of the CDs are in digipak or similar card packaging. I left those as they are. For the others, I kept the disc, liner notes and any other inserts and dumped the boxes themselves. I did this even in the case of the many CamJazz CDs in the collection (Enrico Pieranunzi, John Taylor, Martial Solal and others), though CamJazz use an unusually robust and appealing type of box. Getting rid of the boxes reduced the weight and bulk of the discs substantially. What used to take up two large boxes now occupies one small one. Of course this will destroy any resale value of the discs, but I‚Äôd be surprised if they had any to begin with.

I‚Äôm going to try to find some of the card CD sleeves that used to be common, and glue the liner notes to them. I often thought about doing this years ago, so that the CDs would take up much less space, but I suppose I didn‚Äôt have the incentive to do so until I faced the prospect of paying to have them moved from one country to another. I‚Äôm looking forward to playing them again after a gap of almost 12 years.
items.summary: My CD collection has been languishing unplayed in a French attic since 2011. I wanted to bring the discs home. But not their ‚Äújewel‚Äù cases, which only add bulk and weight.

items.title: Talk about books, print edition ‚Äî again
items.content_html:
Towards the end of 2021, when Talk about books was one year old, I thought about starting a print edition of the publication (which, at the time, I was still calling a newsletter). In the event, I did something completely different: I moved Talk about books from Substack, its original home, to Micro.blog, which had just begun to offer a newsletter feature. Now, a year on from that, I‚Äôve revived the idea of a print edition.

As I said in the original post, I think it‚Äôs likely that I won‚Äôt find anybody who is willing to pay to receive a printed edition of Talk about books. If that‚Äôs the case, I‚Äôm not going to be surprised or disappointed: it‚Äôs important to me that a physical, tangible edition should exist, and be available to readers, even if nobody takes up the option. If there are no takers, it won‚Äôt cost me anything to produce, and if there‚Äôs just a handful, the costs will be proportionately small.

When I was originally thinking about this I intended to use Substack‚Äôs paid subscription feature to collect payment for the print option. Now that Talk about books is no longer on Substack I need to find an alternative method.

I‚Äôm planning to offer three tiers: at the top, the printed publication. On average, this will consist of 16‚Äì20 A5 pages (four or five A4 sheets folded into a booklet), and contain a little over 2,000 words on average. The cost will be ‚Ç¨12 per month and there will be 26 issues a year.

The middle tier will consist of the A5 PDF, exactly the same as the printed edition except that the pages will be in the right order for reading on screen (rather than for printing on both sides of A4 sheets). That will be sent by email and will cost ‚Ç¨3 per month or ‚Ç¨30 a year.

The third tier will, of course, be exactly what we have at the moment: each post sent by email and RSS, and archived on the web at https://letter.talkaboutbooks.net/tabarchive. It will remain free to read, as it has been since the start.

I‚Äôm going to treat the next Talk about books post, on 11-Jan-2023, as a test run, to try to gauge interest. The screen PDF (i.e. the middle tier) will be free to download, and there‚Äôll be a link to it in the usual email. And if you‚Äôll send me ‚Ç¨6 and your postal address, I‚Äôll mail you a printed copy.

The money can be sent by PayPal to art@talkaboutbooks.net, which is also where you can send the postal address and any comments or suggestions you might have (whether or not you want a printed copy). I‚Äôm looking forward to hearing from you.

You can sign up for the email posts (which are free, and sent out every two weeks) here:

Or get the RSS feed here.
items.summary: A year ago, I was thinking about a print edition of my Substack, but I did something else instead. It‚Äôs an idea whose time has come back.

items.title: Publishers and short stories
items.content_html:
It‚Äôs a truism that collections of short stories are a hard sell. Publishers are reluctant to take them because they know there‚Äôs a good chance that readers won‚Äôt be willing to buy them. I tended to think of this as simply the way things are, without really wondering why it should be so. It‚Äôs for that reason that I had a kind of an ‚Äúaha!‚Äù moment in April 2018, when I saw a tweet from Sin√©ad Gleeson, the editor of The Long Gaze Back, a collection of short stories by Irish women. Gleeson quoted Mavis Gallant, who wrote in the Preface to her 1950 Collected Stories:

Stories are not chapters of novels. They should not be read one after another, as if they were meant to follow along. Read one. Shut the book. Read something else. Come back later. Stories can wait.

If story collections are not to be read as though they were novels, perhaps an approximately novel-length volume in which the stories are listed like chapters is not the best delivery mechanism for them. What is that volume, after all, but an invitation to the reader to read them in sequence, one leading on to the next, in about the same time as it would take her to read a novel? Does that explain why readers, and therefore publishers, are wary of the collection? Because the reader knows from experience that the volume is likely to remain unfinished, unreturned-to, a long-standing reproach?

The preceding paragraphs originally formed part of a post I wrote back in 2018 about where to read short stories online. The rest of the post is long out of date and I deleted it at least 18 months ago. But last weekend, in the last Talk about books post of 2022, I was writing about short stories and I‚Äôd have liked to include a link to these paragraphs, so I thought I‚Äôd resurrect them as a short, standalone post.

And, as we‚Äôre on the subject of reading short stories online, here‚Äôs my too seldom updated list.
items.summary: Short stories aren‚Äôt novels. So maybe it‚Äôs not a good idea that collections and anthologies so often take the same size and shape as a novel.

items.title: Why I don‚Äôt trust Bookshop.org
items.content_html:
I haven‚Äôt always been convinced that independent bookshops are a vital part of our culture. I wrote about my ambivalence two years ago. I was already leaning steeply towards the view that indie booksellers are necessary, they‚Äôre under threat and we need to do whatever we can to keep them in business. In the two years since, I‚Äôve come down firmly on that side.

The threat still comes from Amazon, who still dominate the market for books and act like a ruthless predator in that market and others. In my earlier post, I didn‚Äôt mention Bookshop.org, a company which positions itself as the antidote to Amazon. I may not have heard of it at the time, as its operations were confined to the United States then. It opened a UK division at the end of 2020. If I had heard of it, I probably hadn‚Äôt looked closely at its method of carrying out those operations.

Bookshop.org says its mission is ‚Äúto financially support local, independent bookshops‚Äù. The way it goes about doing this is a bit surprising. When you buy a book through Bookshop.org the order goes from that website straight to the book wholesaler (that‚Äôs Gardners in the UK) who dispatch it to you. The actual independent local bookshop isn‚Äôt directly involved in the transaction and the book doesn‚Äôt come out of its own stock. In fact, it doesn‚Äôt even see the book. However, when you visited the Bookshop.org site, you were asked to choose a bookshop and then brought to the ‚Äúvirtual storefront‚Äù of your choice. If you ordered the book through that virtual storefront, the corresponding bookseller will get a 30% cut of the book‚Äôs price. The independent bookseller is not a necessary part of this system. There‚Äôs something obviously artificial about its involvement.

The 30% that Bookshop.org pays is less than a bookseller would normally get from a book sold directly in their physical shop. According to this New Statesman story, they would usually expect between 42% and 50% of the price. In that case, though, the bookseller would have to order and stock the book and make place for it on their shelves. In the case of the Bookshop.org sale, they don‚Äôt have to do any of that, so arguably the smaller percentage is a fair cut.

The New Statesman piece, which appeared only a month after Bookshop.org opened in the UK, and might not reflect the present position, suggests that Bookshop.org may not so much be taking customers away from Amazon as drawing them from the very bookshops it‚Äôs supposed to be supporting. Is it possible that the people buying through Bookshop.org are largely the people who would otherwise have bought the book over the counter in a physical shop?

What bothers me is that a system whose professed aim is to help independent bookstores looks more like a practical demonstration of their supposed irrelevance. The Bookshop.org system would work just fine without any independent booksellers at all. If the economics of this business model ever become unworkable, the indie bookshops‚Äô 30% is likely to be the first cost to be cut. I shouldn‚Äôt be surprised if Bookshop.org ends up doing more harm than good to independent booksellers.

I haven‚Äôt bought anything through Bookshop.org myself. I no longer live in the UK, and I don‚Äôt particularly want to test whether the wholesalers will post to Ireland. More importantly, I suspect that there are more effective ways to support independent local bookshops. I now live 11 Km from Westport, in County Mayo. That town has at least four bookshops that I can think of off the top of my head, including the inviting Tertulia. Castlebar, just a little further away, has the excellent Castle Books. Even the small town of Louisburgh is well served by Books at One (pictured). I‚Äôve been to Galway four or five times this year and bought books in several shops there.

If I can‚Äôt immediately find a book that I want in a local shop, I tend to look online first at Kennys in Galway. In the past, if I still couldn‚Äôt find the book on Kennys‚Äô site, I‚Äôd try Alibris, though I‚Äôve been avoiding them recently for reasons that are not directly relevant to the subject of this post.

In practical terms, I suppose my opinion doesn‚Äôt count for much. I live in a place that isn‚Äôt covered by Bookshop.org and that is well served by a choice of independent bookshops. But it bothers me that an initiative that has been hailed as great news for booksellers may not in the end turn out to be as effective as has been suggested.
items.summary: The declared aim of Bookshop.org is to support independent bookshops. The effect may be to make them appear irrelevant.

items.title: Mistaken long: Andrew Marvell and pronouns again
items.content_html:
I‚Äôve been familiar with Andrew Marvell‚Äôs poem, ‚ÄúThe Garden‚Äù, for a long time. I first encountered it in the early 1970s when I was at school. I was entranced by the ideas of the mind as an ‚Äúocean where each kind | Does straight its own resemblance find,‚Äù (ll. 43‚Äì4) and the soul which ‚ÄúCasting the body‚Äôs vest aside‚Äù (l. 51) glides into the boughs of the trees to prepare ‚Äúfor longer flight‚Äù (l. 55). But I forgot about the poem and rediscovered it with delight twenty years later when I went back to college in my thirties to study English (having done Law the first time around). I eventually wrote my doctoral thesis on Marvell; and it was ‚ÄúThe Garden‚Äù that first hooked me on his poetry.

So, it‚Äôs a poem that I‚Äôm quite familiar with, and I‚Äôm embarrassed to have to admit that there‚Äôs something obvious about it that I had never noticed until last week. The second stanza begins:

Fair Quiet, have I found thee here,
And Innocence, thy sister dear!
Mistaken long, I sought you then
In busy companies of men. (ll. 9‚Äì12)

I had often noticed the shift from ‚Äúthee‚Äù and ‚Äúthy‚Äù in the first two lines of this stanza, to ‚Äúyou‚Äù in the third, but I had never before paid attention to the reason for this shift. Suddenly it struck me that ‚Äúyou‚Äù is ‚Äî of course! ‚Äî plural: the speaker is no longer speaking to, and about, ‚ÄúFair Quiet‚Äù alone, but Quiet and Innocence together. Not only had he formerly been seeking Quiet ‚Äúin busy companies of men‚Äù, he‚Äôd also been looking for Innocence in all the same wrong places! He had not only been long mistaken, but doubly so.

We‚Äôre now accustomed to the singular use of ‚Äúyou‚Äù, so it was easy for me to assume that the speaker continued, as he had started, to address a single listener. Now that I‚Äôve seen my error, I think I ought to search through Marvell‚Äôs works to see whether he ever uses ‚Äúyou‚Äù as a singular pronoun and, if so, in what circumstances.

One of the arguments in favour of ‚Äúthe singular they‚Äù is that a similar change in number had happened in the case of ‚Äúyou‚Äù, without that causing confusion or difficulty. Before that change, ‚Äúthou‚Äù, ‚Äúthee‚Äù and ‚Äúthy‚Äù were used informally and between equals, while ‚Äúyou‚Äù and ‚Äúyour‚Äù indicated that one was speaking either to more than one person, or to an individual who deserved or required respect or deference. As we know, ‚Äúthou‚Äù became archaic and now everybody is ‚Äúyou‚Äù, however many or few they are.

But it‚Äôs not really true, is it, that the singularization of ‚Äúyou‚Äù came about without any confusion or misunderstanding? It often seems to me that we‚Äôre constantly looking to reintroduce a distinctively plural version of the second person pronoun. My father used to say ‚Äúyou people‚Äù to make it clear that he was addressing us collectively, not individually. When I lived in Dublin in the late 70s and early 80s, it wasn‚Äôt unusual to hear ‚Äúyous‚Äù performing the same function. I went through a phase of using it myself. And, of course, there‚Äôs ‚Äúy‚Äôall‚Äù.

In short, I think there‚Äôs clearly some value in retaining a distinction between singular and plural pronouns. I‚Äôm not, of course, advocating that we bring back ‚Äúthou‚Äù. But I expect that if (when?) use of the singular they becomes the norm, we‚Äôre likely to see determined attempts to distinguish the plural from it. ‚ÄúThey-all‚Äù perhaps. Or ‚Äútheys‚Äù?
items.summary: I‚Äôve been missing something very obvious about Andrew Marvell‚Äôs poem ‚ÄúThe Garden‚Äù for an embarrassingly long time.

items.title: Newsletter no longer
items.content_html:
Hamish McKenzie, one of the founders of Substack, wrote last month that we should stop thinking of his platform as belonging to a supposed ‚Äúnewsletter economy‚Äù.

The trend that Substack is part of is not a newsletter trend, or even the much-hyped creator economy. We are part of a seismic shift in the media economy that is all about writer and creator ownership and independence.

The idea, he says, is to put writers in control of their own work and in direct contact with their readers, and email newsletters are just a part of the process.

Talk about books was originally on Substack, where I started it just under 2 years ago. In December 2021 Manton Reece, founder of Micro.blog, introduced a newsletter feature there. I was keen to try that out, so I switched over from Substack.

So, though Talk about books is no longer on Substack, I feel that McKenzie‚Äôs observations have some application to it. The fact is that I‚Äôve been feeling uncomfortable calling it a newsletter and referring to the individual posts as ‚Äúissues‚Äù. For a start, it doesn‚Äôt contain any ‚Äúnews‚Äù, just book discussion. I feel as if McKenzie‚Äôs post has given me permission to stop thinking and writing about it in those terms.

I‚Äôm not sure what I should call it instead, though. I‚Äôm thinking of ‚Äúemail letter‚Äù. As against that, it‚Äôs also distributed as an RSS feed and each ‚Äúissue‚Äù originates as a post on Micro.blog. I tend to think of it as a web publication, with the emails being just one way of notifying people about it.

McKenzie is keen to emphasize that the email newsletter has from the start being just one aspect of what Substack offers. They quickly introduced their own web-based Reader (in effect a new RSS reader) and more recently a mobile app (to which a chat feature has just been added). They also have podcasts and video. RSS apart, none of that really interests me, so I‚Äôve been thinking about what additional features I could offer to supplement the fortnightly email.

Before Manton and Micro.blog tempted me away from Substack, I had been thinking of offering a physical, printed copy of the letter by post. When I decided to shift everything over to Micro.blog I shelved that idea because I had to set up and test new Micro.blog templates and separate styles for the emails and the web posts. You probably noticed that was a bit hit and miss for a while, but I‚Äôve now got it as close to the way I want it as email will permit.

Now I think it might be time to resuscitate the printed letter idea. The next Talk about books post, scheduled for 16 November, will be the last of Talk about books‚Äôs second year, so it seems an opportune time to think about new directions. As I said a year ago, I think it‚Äôs entirely possible (actually likely) that nobody will want to pay for a printed version. In that case, it won‚Äôt cost me anything to produce it, so no harm done, but I feel that it‚Äôs important at least to offer the printed option, even if there are no takers.

Of course, since I‚Äôm no longer on Substack, managing the paid subscription element would be more complicated than I originally envisaged, so that‚Äôs another complication I‚Äôll need to consider.
items.summary: Substack doesn‚Äôt want you to think of it as part of ‚Äúthe newsletter economy. The same goes for Talk about books.

items.title: More about Ian McEwan‚Äôs Sweet Tooth: not rushing into print
items.content_html:
My most recent post in Talk about books is about two novels by Ian McEwan, one of them being 2012‚Äôs Sweet Tooth. I wrote that:

In the final chapter, McEwan introduces an extraordinary narrative trick that has the reader frantically searching back through Serena‚Äôs story, trying to work out which parts are reliable and which must be inventions or fabrications. I may write about that trick in a separate post on my personal site.

And here we are. The trick is that the novel, in the narrative voice throughout of a young woman recruited into MI5 after graduating from Cambridge, turns out to have been written entirely by the main male character in an imitation of her voice. Almost nothing in the story reflects the protagonist‚Äôs actual thoughts and feelings ‚Äî though the account of what she did and what happened to her is largely accurate ‚Äî it‚Äôs the ‚Äúauthor‚Äù‚Äôs reconstruction. I say ‚Äúalmost nothing‚Äù because he makes her an offer at the end, one which she has evidently accepted. To avoid getting themselves and others into trouble with the law, they‚Äôll have to delay publication until people have died and memories faded.

A few decades is time enough for you to correct my presumptions on your solitude, to tell me about the rest of your secret work and what really happened between you and Max, and time to insert those paddings of the backward glance: in those days, back then, these were the years of ‚Ä¶ Or how about, ‚ÄúNow that the mirror tells a different story, I can say it and get it out of the way. I really was pretty‚Äù. Too cruel? No need to worry. I‚Äôll add nothing without your say-so. We won‚Äôt be rushing into print. (p. 370; emphasis and ellipsis original).

The book as published contains a different version of ‚Äúwhat really happened‚Äù between Serena and Max from the one Max recounted to Tom, and it includes the passage about the mirror telling a different story, so we infer that it incorporates Serena‚Äôs corrections and ‚Äúpaddings‚Äù.

The paperback came out in 2013 and I must have bought it not long afterwards. As is often the way, I didn‚Äôt read it immediately. I had read a short extract in The Guardian describing Tom Haley ‚Äî a description which read like McEwan‚Äôs unflattering self-portrait. I was keen to read the book but I had other things on my plate. When I eventually got around to Sweet Tooth, I read it with enjoyment but, as I reached the final chapter, a mounting sense of alarm. Oh no, I thought, I think I can see where he‚Äôs going with this.

I spent a large part of 2014 writing the first draft of my only attempt so far at a novel, A Falling Body. I was particularly pleased with the way it ends but as I finished Sweet Tooth, I concluded that I was going to have to change it, because otherwise people would think I‚Äôd stolen the ending straight from McEwan‚Äôs novel. My story, too, purported to be the first-person narrative of the female main character, which turned out to have been written ‚Äúon her behalf‚Äù by one of the men in the story.

So I had used the same narrative device as McEwan had but I hardly need to add that I hadn‚Äôt used it with anything like McEwan‚Äôs subtlety or skill. Not only did the end of A Falling Body seem to be an imitation of McEwan, it looked like a bad, greatly inferior imitation. I needed to rewrite it, obviously. But how was I going to come up with another ending nearly as good as the one I was having to reject? I spent the first eight months of 2015 tinkering with the draft of A Falling Body and rewriting one chapter from scratch, but I never managed to find an alternative ending.

So, I left it as it was. I decided that it didn‚Äôt really matter if people thought I was stealing from McEwan. It was kind of truish anyway. Though I had hit on the ending of A Falling Body before reading Sweet Tooth, the ideas about gender that I‚Äôd like to think informed A Falling Body owed quite a bit to my reading of some of McEwan‚Äôs earlier fiction. So maybe it was fair enough if the borrowing seemed more direct than I had thought it was.

In the end, only about 15 people read A Falling Body all the way through. When I posted it on Medium in multiple parts, the first part got several hundred page views but readership dropped off precipitously. Of the small number of people who did finish it, nobody remarked on the resemblance of the ending to that of McEwan‚Äôs novel.

So, I suppose I got away with the apparent plagiarism. But, though I‚Äôm no longer particularly pleased with or proud of A Falling Body, I‚Äôd rather some more people had read it, even if they ended up calling me out on it.
items.summary: An addendum to my Talk about books post about Ian McEwan‚Äôs spy fiction. The ending of Ian McEwan‚Äôs 2012 novel Sweet Tooth filled me with a heady mix of excitement and dismay.

items.title: Socially acceptable: Louise Nealon, Snowflake (2021)
items.content_html:
The most recent issue of my email newsletter, which I sent out on 8 September, was about two short stories by Louise Nealon, the first of which, ‚ÄúWhat feminism is‚Äù, won the Se√°n √ì Faol√°in prize for 2017. Having been able to find only two stories by Nealon online, and afraid that on their own they wouldn‚Äôt be substantial enough to support a single newsletter post, I had intended to round out that discussion with a few paragraphs on her first novel, Snowflake. Finding that I had written rather more than a few paragraphs and was still not approaching the end of what I wanted to say about the novel, I truncated the newsletter email and held over the discussion of Snowflake for a separate post. Here it is.

As I said in the newsletter, the novel features depression and other mental illness, isolation and loneliness, sudden and brutal death by farm machinery, attempted suicide, guilt, grief and out-of-control drinking. These are far from being unusual themes in Irish fiction but Nealon writes about them in a lighthearted and almost whimsical tone that makes these familiar motifs seem fresh and surprising. I‚Äôm not normally very keen on whimsy but where it‚Äôs used as here to leaven a story that might otherwise be unbearably bleak, it‚Äôs easier to put up with.

The first-person narrator is 18-year-old Debbie, who, when people ask if she‚Äôs considered becoming vegan or takes milk in her tea, tells them that she lives on a dairy farm ‚Äî as if to say she lives on it, but isn‚Äôt really connected to it. The farm belongs to her uncle Billy, who lives in a caravan beside the house occupied by Debbie and her mother, Maeve, and (for the first part of the book at least), Maeve‚Äôs younger lover, James, who does much of the farm work.

Maeve suffers from bipolar disorder (as it‚Äôs eventually diagnosed) and believes she can share other people‚Äôs dreams. She is also given to dancing naked in a patch of nettles, getting stung all over. She explains:

‚ÄúThere is seratonin in them. That‚Äôs why they sting ‚Äî they‚Äôre natural needles that inject you with a happy chemical. It‚Äôs good for you.‚Äù (p. 34)

Maeve had Debbie when she was just 18 ‚Äî the age Debbie is now ‚Äî and has never told anyone who Debbie‚Äôs father is. Debbie thinks it‚Äôs possible she might not know. James is 11 years younger than Maeve: not an outrageous age gap, but it means he‚Äôs just 7 years older than Debbie.

Although the farm is quite near the capital in geographical terms ‚Äî a twenty-minute drive from Maynooth, which is in turn a forty-minute train ride from Dublin ‚Äî Debbie has been in the city only once a year, to see the Christmas lights. Now, she has been accepted into Trinity College to study English literature and she‚Äôs feeling lost and isolated. This too is a familiar theme in Irish fiction but Nealon doesn‚Äôt labour it.

If Maeve‚Äôs dream-sharing is real, it seems that it may have been inherited by her daughter. It‚Äôs possible that this exposure to the dream-states of others has made it necessary for Debbie to innure herself to the suffering of others. Hungover and exhausted, Debbie falls asleep on her feet on a crowded train back to Maynooth. When she wakes, she ‚Äúknows‚Äù that the man who was standing beside her, who has also been asleep, is in a desperate situation:

I‚Äôm just after waking up from being inside his head. And I know how he‚Äôs going to do it. He‚Äôs been thinking about it every day on the train home from work. He‚Äôs planning the best way to kill himself. (p. 101)

But there doesn‚Äôt seem to be anything that Debbie can do with this momentous, shocking information. How do you explain to someone that you‚Äôve involuntarily seen into his most private thoughts?

I ignore my first instinct which is to tap him on the shoulder. What would I say? Give him some sort of cryptic message? Give him a hug? Every scenario I‚Äôm imagining is too dramatic for the everyday end of a commute. So I watch him disappear through the turnstile along with everyone else. (p. 102)

The dreams that make a particular impression on Debbie are ones that depict ‚Äî or predict ‚Äî catastrophic outcomes. As a child, she dreamt the death of a nineteen-year-old boy who accidentally drove his car into the wall of their garden.

I was a boy in the dream and I was driving a car. I can‚Äôt remember much about the dream itself but I remember how it ended. I didn‚Äôt see the sharp bend at the bottom of the hill until the last second. I locked hard and then I felt the ice underneath the tyres and it was graceful, really. And then a beautiful thought went through my head. The world spun me around like the way a woman unexpectedly makes you twirl on the dance floor and you feel a little silly, a bit emasculated really, but it doesn‚Äôt matter ‚Ä¶ (p. 30)

Debbie‚Äôs dream is just a moment or two ahead of reality, not enough for her to be able to do anything to prevent the catastrophe.

Mam says that I woke up screaming before we heard the car crash into the wall. I was inconsolable. It was my fault that the boy died. He had hurtled his way into my head and I had stopped him from going to heaven. He was in too many pieces, like the wreckage of his car that we kept finding in the garden. (pp. 30‚Äì1)

Years later, when James is killed by a rotating power take-off shaft on the farm, Debbie can‚Äôt avoid feeling that she should have been able to prevent his death. It‚Äôs not surprising that, to protect herself from feelings of guilt, Debbie should develop a callous attitude to pain and death. At one point, ‚Äúafraid to go to sleep‚Äù (p. 111), she is out in the yard at night, getting some milk, when she hears a calving cow in distress.

The calf is still in the amniotic sac. I know that‚Äôs bad. Usually, the pink balloon bursts and dangles from the cow‚Äôs tail ‚Ä¶ I watch the cow push the sac out of her like it‚Äôs a giant squid. It slides onto the grass in a slimy bubble. All it needs is a prod or a poke and it would pop. I know that I should call Billy but I wouldn‚Äôt be able to explain why I was out in the yard at this hour. I‚Äôm so tired that I‚Äôm not even sure it‚Äôs happening. (p. 112)

Similarly, when she sees a hedgehog which has fallen through the cattle grid and can‚Äôt escape, she tells Billy not to try to lift it out with a shovel. Two other hedgehogs have already died of starvation in the same trap. ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt be lifting them all out,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt come rushing over pretending to fix it all‚Äù (p. 228). Billy protests:

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a big lump of a yoke. It‚Äôll take at least a couple of days before it starts to starve to death.‚Äù (p. 228)

But Debbie is unmoved. She later learns that Billy has gone ahead and rescued the hedgehog without her knowledge.

Once she has started college, Debbie finds that one way to keep the dreams away is by drinking till she blacks out (p. 124). She is firmly convinced that she has never had sex but the blackouts make it impossible to be absolutely certain. Her best friend, Xanthe, and her doctor both urge her to get tested for sexually transmitted infections, but she balks at that prospect.

When she gets only a 2.2 in her first essay ‚Äî Xanthe got the only first in their group while most of the others got 2.1s ‚Äî Debbie goes to see a counsellor who tells her that she is suffering from anxiety. Debbie is not pleased.

Anxiety is a fancy word for worry, and worrying is not a medical condition. Depression is a fancy word for being sad, but it‚Äôs a stronger synonym. I could forgive myself for getting a 2.2 because of depression. I can‚Äôt forgive myself for getting a 2.2 because I‚Äôm a bit of a worrier. There has been no mention of depression at all yet. There‚Äôs an epidemic of depression among students. Depression is like the 2.1 of mental illnesses and she‚Äôs not even giving that to me. (pp. 137‚Äì8)

Like Debbie, Billy drinks too much and, like her, he does it partly to escape from his own consciousness. But he‚Äôs been doing it a lot longer than she has, and he has some pointers for her as to how to keep it within manageable limits:

‚Äú‚Ä¶ Pace yourself. You‚Äôre looking for the sweet spot where you can act the maggot, but not lose control altogether. There‚Äôs no freedom in that ‚Ä¶‚Äù (p. 190)

For Billy, as for many of their neighbours, alcoholism is a way of life, and it looks as if Debbie will be heading the same way before long. When Debbie eventually gets to see a therapist she can trust, she‚Äôs the woman who used to teach Debbie piano as a child, and a former schoolfriend of Billy‚Äôs.

Billy stopped taking me to piano lessons after someone told him that Audrey Keane had gone to rehab. It is socially acceptable to be an alcholic in our parish as long as you don‚Äôt get treatment for it. Being fond of the drink is a form of survival around here. If Audrey had kept quiet and continued to drink at home, people would have still sent their kids to piano lessons. Audrey‚Äôs problem was admitting that she had a problem, and the problem was with alcohol, the one thing everyone loved. (p. 68)

While Debbie drinks excessively to avoid the dreams that she thinks are not her own but other people‚Äôs, Billy does so because he feels responsible for the death of his mother when he was a child. Like Debbie, he has some faculties that appear vaguely paranormal ‚Äî he‚Äôs a diviner, and not just of water, and he has ‚Äúthe cure‚Äù ‚Äî but he has learned to adopt a matter-of-fact attitude to these, and not take them too seriously until they‚Äôre needed.

Maeve, who is acknowledged to be mentally ill, has no difficulty accepting her apparent ability to share dreams. She has an off-kilter way of perceiving the world but that doesn‚Äôt seem to make her a danger to herself or to anyone else. Debbie and Billy acknowledge that they don‚Äôt really need to keep an eye on her most of the time.

It‚Äôs true that Maeve smashes most of her teeth by repeatedly banging her face against one of the stairs, but she does this more out of grief at the loss of James than from depression or delusion. In contrast, Billy attempts to hang himself, and Debbie has been regularly drinking herself into a stupor in situations where she‚Äôs clearly not safe.

Once Debbie has been seeing her former piano teacher as a therapist for a while, her situation improves:

I had a good sleep last night. The dreams are still there. I‚Äôm just able to let them come and go. Xanthe bought me a bag of Guatemalan worry beads that I keep under my pillow ‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm dressed in someone else‚Äôs clothes that I found in a charity shop last week. I find it comforting to wear clothes that already have a history of their own. (p. 351; ellipsis added)

The two short stories and the novel are thematically quite distinct from each other. Nealon‚Äôs publishing deal is for two books, so I‚Äôm looking forward to the second. But I really hope she‚Äôll get the chance to write some more short stories.
items.summary: In her first novel Louise Nealon writes about depression and other mental illness, isolation and loneliness, sudden and brutal death by farm machinery, attempted suicide, guilt, grief and out-of-control drinking, in an almost whimsical way.
